paragraph.paragraph: The simplest way to deploy EiffelEnvision projects is through the use of the vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment projects available in the Enterprise, or better, editions of Visual Studio .NET 2003. EiffelEnvision integrates tightly into the deployment mechanism provided by the Visual Studio .NET IDE, providing a fast and easy way to package and distribute your projects.

Before attempting to deploy EiffelEnvision projects using the vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment projects , please be sure to read the
deploy_setup.xml deployment prerequisites section of this documentation.

For those with the Standard edition of Visual Studio .NET 2003, or those who do not want to use the vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment projects , please refer to deploy_no_set.xml deploying projects outside of Visual Studio .NET for information of deploying EiffelEnvision projects without using the vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment projects .

To begin deploying EiffelEnvision projects using one of the vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment projects , you should be familiar with
vboriDeploymentInVisualStudio 0 deploying projects using Visual Studio .NET 2003 . A knowledge of vbconWhatYouNeedToKnowAboutMicrosoftWindowsInstaller
Microsoft Windows Installer will also help greatly when it comes to finer grained customization of your deployment project.

If you have not already done so, you will need to
vbtskCreatingOrAddingSetupProject 0 create a deployment project using the
vxurfNewProjectDialog 0 new project dialog .

When using a vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment project, the primary way to include the built results of a project is through vbtskAddingRemovingProjectOutputs 0 adding a project output to the deployment project. EiffelEnvision projects define 4 different project outputs for inclusion in your deployment project.
Primary Output
Debug Symbols
Content Files
Source Files
Primary Output
The result of compilation. This will be the file containing an assembly manifest as well as reference assembly modules.
Debug Symbols
Any generated _core_The_..PDB_Files 0 debugging information database files (*.PDB) generated during compilation. PDB files are only generated when the active project configuration's
*Generate Debug Information is set to Yes.
Content Files
Files located in the project that are considered to be content files. Such files include Bitmaps, Icons, Cursors, etc.
Source Files
Contains all of the project source files found at the project location or in any of its subfolders.

It may be necessary to exclude certain files when adding items to the deployment project using a
#project_outputs project output . For information on how to do this using vbconSetupProjects 0 setup and deployment projects, please refer to vxtskExcludingFilesFromProjectOutputGroup 0 excluding files from a project output group .

Once you have configured your deployment project, all that remains is to vxtskPrepareandManageBuilds 0 build it. If you have not already built your EiffelEnvision project(s), selecting to vxtskPrepareandManageBuilds 0 build
the deployment project will also build the EiffelEnvision project(s) in the same build session.

If you require to deploy you project source files, you will simply need to include all of the files and subfolders located in the project folder, with the exception of the bin and obj folders. All paths stored in an EiffelEnvision project file are relative to the project location, making the project portable. EiffelEnvision also permits the use of tt environment variables in all paths, making the project even more portable than projects created for other languages in Visual Studio .NET.
